keyTakeAways: Military jackets, particularly the Hussar pelisse, are making a significant comeback in high fashion.
Celebrity influencers like Jodie Turner-Smith, Zendaya, and Jenna Ortega are prominently wearing military-style outerwear at fashion events and red carpets.
The trend has historical roots in the 18th century and was popularized by musicians such as Jimi Hendrix, The Beatles, and others, often as a form of anti-establishment or artistic expression.
Luxury fashion brands like Saint Laurent, Balmain, Gucci, Marc Jacobs, and Dior have reinterpreted the Hussar jacket in modern, stylish ways.
The trend is now being embraced across global fashion catwalks, including Jonathan Anderson’s Dior debut and other designers such as McQueen, Vaquera, and Ann Demeulemeester.
Data from fashion analytics shows a 300% increase in global searches for 'Hussar jacket' in October 2025 compared to the previous month, indicating widespread public interest.

namedEntities.name: Jodie Turner-Smith
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is a key figure in the current fashion resurgence of military jackets, being seen wearing a black, white and red Hussar-style jacket at the Victoria’s Secret after-party in New York, which highlights the trend's visibility among celebrities and fashion insiders.

namedEntities.name: Zendaya
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is featured in the article for wearing a metallic, fur-trimmed dress-coat at Louis Vuitton, drawing inspiration from King Louis XVI, reinforcing the historical and rebellious roots of military-style fashion in modern styling.

namedEntities.name: Jenna Ortega
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is highlighted for wearing a gothic black Hussar vest with gold embroidery at Dior, demonstrating how the military jacket style is being reinterpreted in diverse, artistic, and edgy fashion contexts.

namedEntities.name: Jimi Hendrix
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is historically significant as one of the first major cultural figures to subvert and popularize the Hussar pelisse in a non-military context, wearing it with vibrant scarves and blouses, influencing the bohemian and anti-establishment aesthetic of the style.

namedEntities.name: The Beatles
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Their use of decorated military coats on the cover of 'Sergeant Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band' helped establish the style as a symbol of anti-war and anti-establishment sentiment, shaping its cultural legacy.

namedEntities.name: Kate Moss
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She helped mainstream the military jacket trend in 2005 by wearing an ivory Hussar jacket at Glastonbury, bridging the gap between music culture and fashion.

namedEntities.name: Keburia
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A Georgian-based brand that sold the Hussar jacket worn by Jodie Turner-Smith, illustrating how modern fashion brands are contributing to the revival of this historical style.

namedEntities.name: Saint Laurent
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Reinterpreted the Hussar jacket in a modern, luxurious way, contributing to its resurgence in high fashion.

namedEntities.name: Balmain
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Included the Hussar jacket in its modern designs, helping to popularize the style in luxury fashion.

namedEntities.name: Gucci
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Reinterpreted the Hussar jacket in modern collections, contributing to the trend’s visibility in high fashion.

namedEntities.name: Marc Jacobs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Presented a cream wool Hussar jacket in 2002 with red trim and gold stitching, inspired by Jimi Hendrix’s style, marking a pivotal moment in the style’s modern renaissance.

namedEntities.name: Dior
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Featured the Hussar jacket in Jonathan Anderson’s debut menswear collection, signaling its return to high fashion catwalks.

namedEntities.name: McQueen
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Included the Hussar jacket in recent collections, reinforcing its presence in contemporary fashion.

namedEntities.name: Vaquera
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Featured the Hussar jacket in recent collections, contributing to the trend’s visibility across fashion houses.

namedEntities.name: Ann Demeulemeester
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Included the Hussar jacket in recent collections, adding to the global fashion revival of the style.

namedEntities.name: Molly Rooyakkers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Runs the fashion analytics account @styleanalytics and provided data showing a 300% increase in searches for 'Hussar jacket' in October 2025, indicating strong public and digital engagement with the trend.

namedEntities.name: Victoria’s Secret
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Served as a venue where Jodie Turner-Smith wore the military jacket, emphasizing the trend's visibility in major fashion events and pop culture settings.

namedEntities.name: Louis Vuitton
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hosted a fashion show where Zendaya appeared in a military-style dress-coat, linking the style to high-profile runway events.

namedEntities.name: Glastonbury
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A venue where Kate Moss wore the Hussar jacket, illustrating the style’s transition from music culture to mainstream fashion.

namedEntities.name: Hussar jacket
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The central fashion trend discussed, with historical and cultural roots in 18th-century military attire, now being revived and reinterpreted in modern fashion.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Hussar jacket, a historical military garment originating from the 18th century, is experiencing a major revival in contemporary fashion. Celebrities such as Jodie Turner-Smith, Zendaya, and Jenna Ortega are prominently wearing the style at fashion events and red carpets, reinforcing its cultural relevance. The trend has deep roots in music and counterculture, notably through Jimi Hendrix and The Beatles, who used military coats to express anti-establishment and anti-war sentiments. Modern luxury fashion brands like Saint Laurent, Gucci, Marc Jacobs, and Dior have reinterpreted the style, bringing it into high fashion. The resurgence is further validated by a 300% increase in global searches for 'Hussar jacket' in October 2025, indicating a growing public interest and cultural resonance beyond the fashion world.
title: Look of the Week: From Jimi Hendrix to Jodie Turner-Smith, why fashion loves a military jacket
